Limits of Functions

Definition

Given a function f ⁣:D→R\func{f}{D}{\R}f:D→R, we say that lim⁡x→af(x)=L\displaystyle\lim_{x\to a} f\p{x} = Lx→alim​f(x)=L if for every sequence {xn}n⊆D∖{a}\set{x_n}_n \subseteq D \setminus \set{a}{xn​}n​⊆D∖{a} such that xn→ax_n \to axn​→a, we have lim⁡n→∞f(xn)=L\displaystyle\lim_{n\to\infty} f\p{x_n} = Ln→∞lim​f(xn​)=L.

Compare with the definition of continuity:

f ⁣:D→R\func{f}{D}{\R}f:D→R is continuous at a∈Da \in Da∈D if for every sequence {xn}n⊆D\set{x_n}_n \subseteq D{xn​}n​⊆D such that xn→ax_n \to axn​→a, we have lim⁡n→∞f(xn)=L\displaystyle\lim_{n\to\infty} f\p{x_n} = Ln→∞lim​f(xn​)=L.

The difference here is that in continuity, the terms of the sequence are allowed to be aaa, but in the definition of a limit, the elements of your sequence are not allowed to be aaa. Beyond that, there's not much else to say. Everything is defined in terms of sequences, so as you would expect, all the usual limit laws apply.

Example 1.

Show that lim⁡x→1(x1/3−1x−1)(x2+1)=23\displaystyle\lim_{x\to1} \p{\frac{x^{1/3} - 1}{x - 1}}\p{x^2 + 1} = \frac{2}{3}x→1lim​(x−1x1/3−1​)(x2+1)=32​.
Solution.

Recall that a3−b3=(a−b)(a2+ab+b2)a^3 - b^3 = \p{a - b}\p{a^2 + ab + b^2}a3−b3=(a−b)(a2+ab+b2). If we set a=x1/3a = x^{1/3}a=x1/3 and b=1b = 1b=1, then

x−1=(x1/3)3−1=(x1/3−1)(x2/3+x1/3+1),x - 1 = \p{x^{1/3}}^3 - 1 = \p{x^{1/3} - 1}\p{x^{2/3} + x^{1/3} + 1},x−1=(x1/3)3−1=(x1/3−1)(x2/3+x1/3+1),

so

x1/3−1x−1=x1/3−1(x1/3−1)(x2/3+x1/3+1)=1x2/3+x1/3+1  ⟹  lim⁡x→1x1/3−1x−1=lim⁡x→11x2/3+x1/3+1=13.\begin{gathered} \frac{x^{1/3} - 1}{x - 1} = \frac{x^{1/3} - 1}{\p{x^{1/3} - 1}\p{x^{2/3} + x^{1/3} + 1}} = \frac{1}{x^{2/3} + x^{1/3} + 1} \\ \implies \lim_{x\to1} \frac{x^{1/3} - 1}{x - 1} = \lim_{x\to1} \frac{1}{x^{2/3} + x^{1/3} + 1} = \frac{1}{3}. \end{gathered}x−1x1/3−1​=(x1/3−1)(x2/3+x1/3+1)x1/3−1​=x2/3+x1/3+11​⟹x→1lim​x−1x1/3−1​=x→1lim​x2/3+x1/3+11​=31​.​

Since polynomials are continuous, we also have lim⁡x→1(x2+1)=2\displaystyle\lim_{x\to1} \p{x^2 + 1} = 2x→1lim​(x2+1)=2, so by the limit laws,

lim⁡x→1(x1/3−1x−1)(x2+1)=(lim⁡x→1x1/3−1x−1)(lim⁡x→1(x2+1))=13⋅2=23.\lim_{x\to1} \p{\frac{x^{1/3} - 1}{x - 1}}\p{x^2 + 1} = \p{\lim_{x\to1} \frac{x^{1/3} - 1}{x - 1}} \p{\lim_{x\to1} \p{x^2 + 1}} = \frac{1}{3} \cdot 2 = \frac{2}{3}.x→1lim​(x−1x1/3−1​)(x2+1)=(x→1lim​x−1x1/3−1​)(x→1lim​(x2+1))=31​⋅2=32​.

Derivatives

Definition

Let I⊆RI \subseteq \RI⊆R be an interval and f ⁣:I→R\func{f}{I}{\R}f:I→R be a function. Then fff is differentiable at a∈Ia \in Ia∈I if

f′(a)=lim⁡x→af(x)−f(a)x−af'\p{a} = \lim_{x\to a} \frac{f\p{x} - f\p{a}}{x - a}f′(a)=x→alim​x−af(x)−f(a)​

exists and is finite. In this case, we say f′(a)f'\p{a}f′(a) is the derivative of fff at aaa.

Here are some very useful formulas for calculating derivatives:

Proposition

Suppose f,gf, gf,g are differentiable at a∈Ra \in \Ra∈R and let c∈Rc \in \Rc∈R. Then

  1. cfcfcf is differentiable at aaa and (cf)′(a)=cf′(a)\p{cf}'\p{a} = cf'\p{a}(cf)′(a)=cf′(a).
  2. f+gf + gf+g is differentiable at aaa and (f+g)′(a)=f′(a)+g′(a)\p{f + g}'\p{a} = f'\p{a} + g'\p{a}(f+g)′(a)=f′(a)+g′(a).
  3. (product rule) fgfgfg is differentiable at aaa and (fg)′(a)=f′(a)g(a)+f(a)g′(a)\p{fg}'\p{a} = f'\p{a}g\p{a} + f\p{a}g'\p{a}(fg)′(a)=f′(a)g(a)+f(a)g′(a).
  4. (quotient rule) If g(a)≠0g\p{a} \neq 0g(a)=0, then fg\frac{f}{g}gf​ is differentiable at aaa and (fg)′(a)=f′(a)g(a)−f(a)g′(a)[g(a)]2\p{\frac{f}{g}}'\p{a} = \frac{f'\p{a}g\p{a} - f\p{a}g'\p{a}}{\br{g\p{a}}^2}(gf​)′(a)=[g(a)]2f′(a)g(a)−f(a)g′(a)​.
Theorem (chain rule)

Let a∈Ra \in \Ra∈R. If fff is differentiable at g(a)g\p{a}g(a) and ggg is differentiable at aaa, then f∘gf \circ gf∘g is differentiable at aaa and (f∘g)′(a)=f′(g(a))g′(a)\p{f \circ g}'\p{a} = f'\p{g\p{a}} g'\p{a}(f∘g)′(a)=f′(g(a))g′(a).

The rest of the notes will be dedicated to examples, since there's not much else to talk about.

Example 2.
(28.8)

Let f(x)=x2f\p{x} = x^2f(x)=x2 for xxx rational and f(x)=0f\p{x} = 0f(x)=0 for xxx irrational. Show that fff is differentiable at x=0x = 0x=0.
Solution.

First, let's look at a wrong answer:

Notice that f′(x)=2xf'\p{x} = 2xf′(x)=2x if xxx is rational. Thus, f′(0)=0f'\p{0} = 0f′(0)=0.

The problem with this statement is that fff is not continuous if x≠0x \neq 0x=0, which means that f′(x)f'\p{x}f′(x) doesn't exist for x≠0x \neq 0x=0. As a result, "f′(x)f'\p{x}f′(x) if xxx is rational" is meaningless. This tells us that our formulas above won't be useful for this problem, and we'll have to do it directly from the definition.

We want to calculate lim⁡x→0f(x)−f(0)x−0\lim_{x\to0} \frac{f\p{x} - f\p{0}}{x - 0}limx→0​x−0f(x)−f(0)​, so it'll be a good idea to see what the function in the limit looks like. If x≠0x \neq 0x=0, then

f(x)−f(0)x−0=f(x)x={xif x is rational,0otherwise.\frac{f\p{x} - f\p{0}}{x - 0} = \frac{f\p{x}}{x} = \begin{cases} x & \text{if } x \text{ is rational}, \\ 0 & \text{otherwise}. \end{cases}x−0f(x)−f(0)​=xf(x)​={x0​if x is rational,otherwise.​

This limit should be 000, so let's try to prove that. Let {xn}n\set{x_n}_n{xn​}n​ be a sequence such that xn≠0x_n \neq 0xn​=0 for all nnn and xn→0x_n \to 0xn​→0. Let ε>0\epsilon > 0ε>0, so by definition, there exists N∈RN \in \RN∈R such that if n>Nn > Nn>N, then ∣xn∣<ε\abs{x_n} < \epsilon∣xn​∣<ε. Thus,

∣f(xn)−f(0)xn−0∣={∣xn∣if xn is rational,0otherwise<ε,\begin{aligned} \abs{\frac{f\p{x_n} - f\p{0}}{x_n - 0}} &= \begin{cases} \abs{x_n} & \text{if } x_n \text{ is rational}, \\ 0 & \text{otherwise} \end{cases} \\ &< \epsilon, \end{aligned}∣∣​xn​−0f(xn​)−f(0)​∣∣​​={∣xn​∣0​if xn​ is rational,otherwise​<ε,​

since it's less than ε\epsilonε in both cases. Thus, because {xn}n\set{x_n}_n{xn​}n​ was an arbitrary sequence,

f′(0)=lim⁡x→0f(x)−f(0)x−0=0.f'\p{0} = \lim_{x\to0} \frac{f\p{x} - f\p{0}}{x - 0} = 0.f′(0)=x→0lim​x−0f(x)−f(0)​=0.
Example 3.
(28.14)

Suppose fff is differentiable at aaa. Prove:

  1. lim⁡h→0f(a+h)−f(a)h=f′(a)\displaystyle \lim_{h\to0} \frac{f\p{a + h} - f\p{a}}{h} = f'\p{a}h→0lim​hf(a+h)−f(a)​=f′(a)
  2. lim⁡h→0f(a+h)−f(a−h)2h=f′(a)\displaystyle \lim_{h\to0} \frac{f\p{a + h} - f\p{a - h}}{2h} = f'\p{a}h→0lim​2hf(a+h)−f(a−h)​=f′(a)
Solution.

  1. Since fff is differentiable at aaa, we know that for any sequence {xn}n\set{x_n}_n{xn​}n​ such that xn≠ax_n \neq axn​=a and xn→ax_n \to axn​→a, we have

    f′(a)=lim⁡n→∞f(xn)−f(a)xn−a.f'\p{a} = \lim_{n\to\infty} \frac{f\p{x_n} - f\p{a}}{x_n - a}.f′(a)=n→∞lim​xn​−af(xn​)−f(a)​.

    Let {hn}n\set{h_n}_n{hn​}n​ be a sequence such that hn≠0h_n \neq 0hn​=0 and hn→0h_n \to 0hn​→0. Notice that a+hn≠aa + h_n \neq aa+hn​=a for all nnn and a+hn→0a + h_n \to 0a+hn​→0, so if we set xn=a+hnx_n = a + h_nxn​=a+hn​, we can apply the equation above to get

    lim⁡n→∞f(a+hn)−f(a)hn=lim⁡n→∞f(a+hn)−f(a)(a+hn)−a=lim⁡n→∞f(xn)−f(a)xn−a=f′(a).\begin{aligned} \lim_{n\to\infty} \frac{f\p{a + h_n} - f\p{a}}{h_n} &= \lim_{n\to\infty} \frac{f\p{a + h_n} - f\p{a}}{\p{a + h_n} - a} \\ &= \lim_{n\to\infty} \frac{f\p{x_n} - f\p{a}}{x_n - a} \\ &= f'\p{a}. \end{aligned}n→∞lim​hn​f(a+hn​)−f(a)​​=n→∞lim​(a+hn​)−af(a+hn​)−f(a)​=n→∞lim​xn​−af(xn​)−f(a)​=f′(a).​

    Since {hn}n\set{h_n}_n{hn​}n​ was an arbitrary sequence, it follows that

    lim⁡h→0f(a+h)−f(a)h=f′(a).\lim_{h\to0} \frac{f\p{a + h} - f\p{a}}{h} = f'\p{a}.h→0lim​hf(a+h)−f(a)​=f′(a).

  2. Notice that

    f(a+h)−f(a−h)2h=f(a+h)−f(a)+f(a)−f(a−h)2h=12(f(a+h)−f(a)h+f(a)−f(a−h)h)=12(f(a+h)−f(a)h+f(a+(−h))−f(a)(−h)).\begin{aligned} \frac{f\p{a + h} - f\p{a - h}}{2h} &= \frac{f\p{a + h} - f\p{a} + f\p{a} - f\p{a - h}}{2h} \\ &= \frac{1}{2} \p{\frac{f\p{a + h} - f\p{a}}{h} + \frac{f\p{a} - f\p{a - h}}{h}} \\ &= \frac{1}{2} \p{\frac{f\p{a + h} - f\p{a}}{h} + \frac{f\p{a + \p{-h}} - f\p{a}}{\p{-h}}}. \end{aligned}2hf(a+h)−f(a−h)​​=2hf(a+h)−f(a)+f(a)−f(a−h)​=21​(hf(a+h)−f(a)​+hf(a)−f(a−h)​)=21​(hf(a+h)−f(a)​+(−h)f(a+(−h))−f(a)​).​

    We can calculate the limit of both terms in the parentheses by the definition of the derivative, so by the limit laws,

    lim⁡h→0f(a+h)−f(a−h)2h=lim⁡h→012(f(a+h)−f(a)h+f(a+(−h))−f(a)(−h))=12(f′(a)+f′(a))=f′(a).\begin{aligned} \lim_{h\to0} \frac{f\p{a + h} - f\p{a - h}}{2h} &= \lim_{h\to0} \frac{1}{2} \p{\frac{f\p{a + h} - f\p{a}}{h} + \frac{f\p{a + \p{-h}} - f\p{a}}{\p{-h}}} \\ &= \frac{1}{2} \p{f'\p{a} + f'\p{a}} \\ &= f'\p{a}. \end{aligned}h→0lim​2hf(a+h)−f(a−h)​​=h→0lim​21​(hf(a+h)−f(a)​+(−h)f(a+(−h))−f(a)​)=21​(f′(a)+f′(a))=f′(a).​
Example 4.

True or false: If lim⁡h→0f(a+h)−f(a−h)2h\displaystyle \lim_{h\to0} \frac{f\p{a + h} - f\p{a - h}}{2h}h→0lim​2hf(a+h)−f(a−h)​ exists and is finite, then fff is differentiable at aaa.
Solution.

False. The exercise above tells us that if the derivative exists, then we can calculate f′(a)f'\p{a}f′(a) using the above formula. If the derivative doesn't exist, then the formula may no longer be true. For example, if f(x)=∣x∣f\p{x} = \abs{x}f(x)=∣x∣, then

lim⁡h→0f(a+h)−f(a−h)2h=lim⁡h→0∣h∣−∣−h∣2h=0,\lim_{h\to0} \frac{f\p{a + h} - f\p{a - h}}{2h} = \lim_{h\to0} \frac{\abs{h} - \abs{-h}}{2h} = 0,h→0lim​2hf(a+h)−f(a−h)​=h→0lim​2h∣h∣−∣−h∣​=0,

but fff is not differentiable at x=0x = 0x=0.
Example 5.
(28.16)

Let fff be a function defined on an open interval III containing aaa. Show that f′(a)f'\p{a}f′(a) exists if and only if there is a function ε(x)\epsilon\p{x}ε(x) defined on III and a real number bbb such that

f(x)−f(a)=(x−a)(b−ε(x))andlim⁡x→aε(x)=0.f\p{x} - f\p{a} = \p{x - a}\p{b - \epsilon\p{x}} \quad\text{and}\quad \lim_{x\to a} \epsilon\p{x} = 0.f(x)−f(a)=(x−a)(b−ε(x))andx→alim​ε(x)=0.
Solution.

"  ⟹  \implies⟹"

Suppose f′(a)f'\p{a}f′(a) exists. Let's try to reverse engineer what ε\epsilonε and bbb would have to be:

f(x)−f(a)=(x−a)(b−ε(x))  ⟹  ε(x)=b−f(x)−f(a)x−a.f\p{x} - f\p{a} = \p{x - a}\p{b - \epsilon\p{x}} \implies \epsilon\p{x} = b - \frac{f\p{x} - f\p{a}}{x - a}.f(x)−f(a)=(x−a)(b−ε(x))⟹ε(x)=b−x−af(x)−f(a)​.

For ε(x)\epsilon\p{x}ε(x) to tend to 000 as x→0x \to 0x→0, we would need b=f′(a)b = f'\p{a}b=f′(a), by the definition of the derivative. Now let's prove that this works:

Technically, ε\epsilonε is defined on I∖{a}I \setminus \set{a}I∖{a}, but its value at x=ax = ax=a doesn't matter since we're taking limits, so we can set it to be any number we like to get a function defined on III. Then

f(x)−f(a)=(x−a)(f′(a)−ε(x))f\p{x} - f\p{a} = \p{x - a}\p{f'\p{a} - \epsilon\p{x}}f(x)−f(a)=(x−a)(f′(a)−ε(x))

just by definition of ε(x)\epsilon\p{x}ε(x), and by our choice of bbb, we get lim⁡x→aε(x)=0\displaystyle\lim_{x\to a} \epsilon\p{x} = 0x→alim​ε(x)=0 automatically.

"  ⟸  \impliedby⟸"

Suppose that ε(x)\epsilon\p{x}ε(x) and bbb exist as in the problem statement. By rearranging the equation in the problem statement and applying limit laws,

f(x)−f(a)x−a=b−ε(x)  ⟹  lim⁡x→af(x)−f(a)x−a=lim⁡x→a(b−ε(x))=b−lim⁡x→aε(x)=b,\begin{aligned} \frac{f\p{x} - f\p{a}}{x - a} &= b - \epsilon\p{x} \\ \implies \lim_{x\to a} \frac{f\p{x} - f\p{a}}{x - a} &= \lim_{x\to a} \p{b - \epsilon\p{x}} \\ &= b - \lim_{x\to a} \epsilon\p{x} \\ &= b, \end{aligned}x−af(x)−f(a)​⟹x→alim​x−af(x)−f(a)​​=b−ε(x)=x→alim​(b−ε(x))=b−x→alim​ε(x)=b,​

so by definition of the derivative, f′(a)f'\p{a}f′(a) exists and is equal to bbb.
